text: Educators and parents are working hard to achieve these goals, and this initiative will help support their work. I am grateful to Vermont PBS as this partnership will give those already doing so much another tool to reach and educate students. (3/3)

I recognize there is no replacement for in-person instruction and the learning that takes place in a classroom but this is an unprecedented public health situation, and we must work together to provide the best possible remote learning opportunities for Vermont’s kids. (2/3)

Today I announced a partnership with @VermontPBS to provide educational content to supplement remote learning for Vermont students and school districts during the COVID-19 outbreak. (1/3) #vtpoli 
https://t.co/8wXc63LVXG

Our state is at its best when Vermonters pull together to help each other. The coming weeks will be very difficult, but united in common purpose, we will face, fight and defeat this virus – and emerge stronger together. 15/15

Support your local Food Bank:
Donate online at https://t.co/5nsY0wS0nt or you can text GIVEHEALTH to 85511. If you're in need of help, click below. 14/15 

 https://t.co/18aOvV7fnP.

Vermonters can also contribute to blood banks, food banks, and other emergency supply efforts. In addition to volunteering, Vermonters can also give back in the following ways: 11/15
We expect to draw upon many skills to meet the challenge of serving those affected by COVID-19, potentially including drivers, food service, construction, IT, security, skilled trades and more. 10/15

Other individuals who do not have medical or healthcare backgrounds but are willing to volunteer their time in Vermont’s response effort can register through the state’s volunteer web portal and indicate their expertise and availability. 9/15

https://t.co/Uy2ZMRhjtb

VT has eased licensing requirements for the purposes of aiding this emergency response. Individuals who are licensed in other states or who were previously licensed should visit the Health Dept. website and review the guide on emergency licensure. 8/15
https://t.co/1BEFAnVNii

This effort is about drawing more skilled personnel, such as retirees or those not currently employed in the healthcare field, into the response and not about redirecting existing healthcare workers. 7/15
The Vermont Medical Reserve Corps is seeking these qualified and experienced volunteers, including: 6/15 https://t.co/yzymXYiLFx
This is needed because Vermont’s existing health care workers are going above and beyond to respond to this challenge as it unfolds, and they are going to need reinforcements. 5/15

The state’s volunteer website directs these individuals to Vermont’s Medical Reserve Corp units, community-based groups of volunteers who can supplement local emergency, health care provider staff and public health resources. 4/15

Those with medical experience or other health care backgrounds and the ability to volunteer are needed to bolster the ranks of Vermont’s current health care workforce. 3/15

https://t.co/XFiGuacep2

As we prepare for a surge in COVID-19 cases expected in the coming weeks, it will require each of us to do our part to ease the burden on our health care system, the struggles of those less fortunate, and, ultimately, to save the lives of our friends and neighbors. 2/15

THREAD: Today, I’m calling all Vermonters into service with the launch of a new website allowing people to sign up for volunteer assistance to support our response to COVID-19. I’m asking every Vermonter to dig deep and find a way to help. #vtpoli 1/15

This morning at 11:00 a.m. I'll be holding another briefing with my team to provide an update on Vermont's ongoing response to COVID-19. You can watch live on most local TV news stations, stream online on their websites, or listen in on the radio on VPR.

This is the first weekend since I issued the Stay Home/Stay Safe Order. This, and other mitigation efforts, are all about slowing the spread of COVID-19. We must all stay home as much as possible. Doing so will save lives. 

Here's a reminder from @vemvt on what it means for you. https://t.co/c6tyVHreR3

Earlier today, I wrote to @POTUS asking him to invoke the Defense Production Act to support states get the supplies we need to fight this pandemic. We urgently need more ventilators and other essential equipment, which will require federal assistance. #vtpoli https://t.co/h5K0htrCEW

Now is a moment of service for all of us. It’s our turn to face a once-in-a-century challenge.
 
But I know Vermonters are up for it. 

We are #VermontStrong 
 
We will get through this, and we’ll do it, together. #vtpoli https://t.co/hR45GEEoAv

I've just signed a stay-at-home order and directed the closure of in-person operations for all non-essential businesses. 

Vermonters: you must stay home. You must stay home to save lives. 

We are all in this together - and we'll get through it, together. https://t.co/foLDJYZIq7

Thank you to my friend Rep. @PeterWelch for giving my team an update on Congress's COVID-19 relief package. The American people and our states need Washington's help to get through this, and Vermonters appreciate your hard work. #vtpoli https://t.co/nxUGPOk08s

We have also extended, among others, personal income tax filing due dates from April 15 to July 15, 2020.
 
This means taxpayers can file and pay these taxes on or before July 15, 2020 without any penalty or interest. Read more below: (2/2) #vtpoli 
https://t.co/3hRbQUZDu9

I have directed the Commissioner of Taxes to provide relief to Vermont businesses who owe Meals and Rooms Tax or Sales and Use Tax until further notice.

Many of our local businesses find themselves unable to meet the filing deadlines due to our necessary mitigation steps. (1/2)
I know we’re going to get through this, not because of any one person or any one action, but because of each of us doing our part. We must stand as Vermonters, united. (2/2) https://t.co/VWY05ZK8dO

This challenge is an opportunity for each of us to step up, even as we must be physically apart. We can unite in our efforts to help those in need. Just like we need to take bold actions to defeat this pandemic, we also need small everyday acts of kindness and goodwill. (1/2) https://t.co/nTcwXJVxOo

On behalf of all Vermonters, I want to extend my deep appreciation to custodial workers across the state who are working overtime to keep our spaces clean and safe. Thank you for helping us slow the spread of COVID-19. https://t.co/KKVx04fRxA

Vermont's educators are as critical to our COVID-19 response as anyone. I am incredibly proud of the selflessness of these public servants at this time of need. (2/3) I want every Vermonter to know I understand the economic and emotional toll COVID-19 is having on each of us. People are hurting and businesses are at risk. Let me assure you, we will pull every lever and turn every dial we can to support folks through this time.#vtpoli

(1/3) Today, @SBAgov approved my disaster declaration request due to COVID-19.

Grocery & food supply workers are critical to our COVID-19 response. To all of you working long & stressful hours, thank you for your hard work. I know all VTers join me in sending our deepest sympathies to the loved ones of the two VTers we sadly lost today. During this difficult time I know some are feeling scared, worried & overwhelmed, but I want you to know we will get through this because we’re all in this together.

I just signed a directive allowing delivery & take-out of alcoholic beverages – including spirit-based drinks – by restaurants, bars & other establishments. Thank you, George! We are all in this together. Thank you for your service to Vermonters during this time of need. #VermontStrong https://t.co/BTJiOleeMN

First, I want to thank heath care workers & our public health officials at @healthvermont for working day and night to keep Vermonters safe and healthy. We owe them a debt of gratitude. THREAD: As we face unprecedented challenges & experience disruptions due to COVID-19, I’ll be highlighting Vermonters for their hard work & the sacrifices they’re making to help us get through these tough times. We will get through this, but it'll take all of us doing our part.

I know there are many disruptions our COVID-19 mitigation steps have caused, but each and every decision we've made is based on science, and will save lives. We must take social distancing seriously. We will get through this. And we'll do it, together. (3/3) #vtpoli

I am also in regular contact with our congressional delegation, @SenatorLeahy, @SenSanders and Rep. @PeterWelch, as well as Vermont legislators, to find ways to help Vermonters whose employment has been impacted by our COVID-19 response. (2/3) #vtpoli

During these challenging times I have instructed @VTLabor to launch an online form for unemployment insurance claims and we’re expanding the number of people in our call center to help. 
To file, visit the link below or call 1-877-214-3330 (1/2) #vtpoli 
 https://t.co/0p1iVPfOie

....so those who are on the front lines of our response can continue to care for the sick, protect the public and manage this evolving challenge. 

I am incredibly proud of the selflessness of these public servants at this time of need. (5/5) https://t.co/WLmDJPJ9Q5

That’s why, even as we ask the public to step back to help slow the spread of this virus, we are asking others, including our educators and child care providers, to step in and provide a critical service.... (4/5)
Teachers, childcare providers and school support staff are going to be as critical to our response as our doctors, nurses and healthcare support staff. (3/5)

My directive also provides for continuity of funding for schools and providers during the period of school dismissal and closure to help preserve these important services for Vermonters post-response. (2/5) #vtpoli

I'm directing childcare centers across the state to close normal operations, but encourage continued operation exclusively where needed to provide services for workers who are essential to Vermont’s ongoing effort in community mitigation of COVID-19. (1/5)
https://t.co/WLmDJPJ9Q5

Lucy Terry's ballad, “Bars Fight,” is considered the oldest known work of poetry by an African American. After settling in Guilford, VT, Lucy – a former slave – successfully argued her family's land theft case before the Vermont Supreme Court in 1785. #BlackHistoryMonth https://t.co/axdTHSqJtq

Born in Corinth, VT, Alexander Twilight was the first African American man to earn a bachelor's degree from an American college. In 1836, he became the first African American man elected to a state legislature, representing Brownington in the VT House of Reps. #BlackHistoryMonth https://t.co/6rpFGLSPWn

Eliza Healy (later know as Sister Mary Magdalen) was born into slavery in Georgia and, in 1903, became the first African American mother superior of a Catholic convent when she assumed leadership of the Villa Barlow convent and school in St. Albans, VT. #BlackHistoryMonth

To learn more about their experiences and important contributions, a good place to start is the Vermont African American Heritage Trail to visit historical sites and hear these stories. #BlackHistoryMonth #ThinkVT https://t.co/zu6wJEIFTN

Our shared values as Vermonters have been shaped by those who came before us. The history of African American Vermonters is woven into the story of our state and we honor this legacy as we celebrate #BlackHistoryMonth

When combined with decreases from 2017-2019, VT employers will pay an average of 30% less in workers’ comp. premiums than before I took office. These savings will help employers of all sizes hire more workers, increase salaries and expand their operations in our state. (2/2) https://t.co/x8vULOL1Xi

As we work to grow the economy, addressing the high cost of doing business in Vermont is critical. This year, I’m happy to announce the largest workers’ compensation insurance rate decrease in decades – without reducing benefits to workers. (1/2) https://t.co/3f77MEJptS

If we accept the challenge, set clear objectives, have the discipline to commit to solutions and follow through, we can reverse these trends. We can restore economic vitality to every corner of our state. We can make Vermont more affordable for every family & business. #VTBudget

The issues we face are significant but none greater than the demographic crisis and the economic challenges it brings... Confronting this crisis now is the only way to preserve our ability to solve problems in the future. #VTBudget

My $3.15M Clean Grid Modernization Package will encourage companies to start & expand here by making R&D work eligible for a tax credit and will provide $2M in capital & technical assistance... and I propose we eliminate the corporate income tax on these job creators. #VTBudget

(2/2) While we wait for Congress to work on a national solution, electric utilities have introduced EV-specific rates and will recommend a pilot program for the collection of revenue from EV charging stations to support long-term transportation maintenance. #VTBudget

(1/2) My budget proposes to invest $3 million to address [obstacles to EV purchases] and help meet our climate & energy goals... We’ll increase funding for incentives, consumer education and support services and… more charging stations on our highways & our workplaces. #VTBudget

On top of everything we’re already doing & everything I’m proposing... I propose committing 25% of all future end-of-year budget surpluses for additional investments that address climate change, specifically for initiatives that support weatherization or electrification.#VTBudget

To create an incentive for military vets to return to VT & join our workforce, I’m again proposing to exempt military retirement pay from the income tax... I hope you’ll join me this year in eliminating the tax on those who devoted their lives in service to our nation. #VTBudget

@VTLabor (4/4) That America is still a land of opportunity for all who seek freedom from oppression, security for their families or, in some cases, just a fresh start. As long as I’m governor, they’ll be welcome right here in Vermont. #VTBudget
@VTLabor (3/4) These efforts not only benefit our state, they also signal we’re committed to the values this nation was built on. #VTBudget
(2/4) This includes funding to @VTLabor that will help communities plan for and explore refugee resettlement and opportunities to welcome more New Americans to Vermont. #VTBudget
(1/4) We’ll continue to advocate for more legal immigration as a way to bring more hardworking people to Vermont to contribute to our economy and grow our workforce. #VTBudget

We’ll also continue our efforts to recruit more people to live and work here. This includes increased funding for @VTLabor's VT Relocation Assistance Program to ensure folks interested in moving here have the info they need about jobs, housing & opportunities available. #VTBudget

We hear about our growing labor shortage in every sector on a daily basis... I ask you to work with me on a $1M incentive to keep graduates from our registered nurse and licensed practical nurse programs right here... filling positions desperately needed by employers. #VTBudget
@VTLabor @VTEducation @VSC_edu @CCV_VT @vttech (2/2) If you’re willing to look at things differently and move with urgency, we can have a unified, statewide training program next year. #VTBudget

(1/2) I’ve also asked @VTLabor and @VTEducation to work with @VSC_edu to align our Adult Ed and Adult CTE system with @CCV_VT, @vttech, our tech centers and regional stakeholders. This will create a seamless pathway from school to training to work. #VTBudget
(3/3) That’s why I’ve directed @VTLabor to work with @VSC_edu and tech centers throughout the state to double the number of apprentices by 2023. #VTBudget

(2/3) Apprenticeships are great opportunities for Vermonters to earn while they learn... These programs are industry-driven, allowing employers to recruit for good jobs they have available. But there’s an opportunity and need to do more. #VTBudget
(1/3) Over the last four years, we’ve added more than 700 apprentices to our workforce, which includes a 36% increase in the number of women in these important programs. #VTBudget

(2/2) Let’s build on this success with an additional $3 million for childcare assistance, and let’s also expand the lottery and commit these new revenues to this initiative each year moving forward. #VTBudget

(1/2) We know the benefits of accessible, affordable childcare for parents, kids and our economy, which is why we’ve worked together to increase funding by 30%—about $10 million—over the last three years, and these investments are working. #VTBudget

To recognize the incredible importance of our larger anchor employers... I propose a $3M VT Capital Investment Incentive Program which encourages these companies to make new upgrades at local facilities & in exchange... they’ll commit to maintain certain payroll levels. #VTBudget

To support more small business growth, I’m proposing a $1 million incentive program through the Vermont Economic Development Authority (VEDA) to provide low-cost loans that convert to no-cost grants after meeting expansion and payroll goals. #VTBudget
(2/2) And when they’re successful, we’ll provide a match to the federal grant to help them grow and create jobs. #VTBudget

(1/2) We’ll also support our small technology businesses with an investment of $1M to help them secure federal Small Business Innovation grants for groundbreaking work done right here in Vermont and to tap into the research capabilities at our colleges and universities. #VTBudget

Let’s make it easier to start, register and operate a business here. Working with @VermontSOS, my budget includes $1 million for a streamlined and online business portal which will make it much easier for them to navigate state government. #VTBudget

As another part of my Community Investment Package, my budget includes $1M for incentives to rehabilitate old homes into decent, affordable, energy efficient rental properties [and] reforms to the Renter Rebate Program... resulting in about $800K more in rebates. #VTBudget

(2/2) Let’s couple the most beautiful state in the nation with an increased investment to remind the 70 million people who live within a six-hour drive that we’re not only a great place to visit but also to live, work, play and, hopefully, invest in. #VTBudget

(1/2) Tourism is a top contributor to our economy. But we’re investing far less than every other state in the region & we compete with them for visitors every single day. My budget includes an additional $1M investment in tourism, economic dev & outdoor rec marketing. #VTBudget

To further strengthen Vermont’s small towns, agriculture and other businesses, I’ve budgeted $750,000 for the Working Lands initiative which will help expand production of quality food, forest products and jobs. #VTBudget

I also propose a $2.8M investment that will leverage another $11.3M in federal funds to complete the Lamoille Valley Rail Trail.... When complete, the activity it will create—along with cross promotion—will strengthen businesses, economies & the quality of life. #VTBudget

The City of Newport is now poised for a once-in-a-generation redevelopment... The capital bill now includes $1.5M to begin the process of helping to revitalize Main St... bring[ing] public & private investment together to implement a larger vision for Newport & the NEK. #VTBudget

Tax Increment Financing [districts] not only create economic growth but also empower communities to shape their own future... I’ll continue to support expanding them across Vermont, including a proposal to make them available to smaller communities. #VTBudget

Today, I propose increasing the downtown & village center tax credits to $4 million—a $1.4 million increase. These dollars support important projects like Springfield’s Woolson Block & Bennington’s Putnam Block that are often the first step in community revitalization. #VTBudget

To put all Vermonters on a better path, we must increase economic opportunity in each of our 14 counties. That’s why this budget includes more investments in downtowns and regional economic centers, and tools to help employers survive and create more good paying jobs. #VTBudget

We’re one of only 4 states moving forward with a prescription importation program… Our estimates show this could save millions… My budget includes resources to continue this important effort, because lowering the costs of prescription drugs is the right thing to do. #VTBudget

(2/2) I recommend we continue to support this work by asking you to authorize the $5.7M for delivery system reforms proposed in budget adjustment on the condition the ACO operate as a non-profit or meet those same transparency standards. #VTBudget

(1/2) In 2018, the providers the state paid through the ACO reduced the amount of money spent on healthcare services by $7.7M. In the same year, providers who were not paid through the ACO spent $1.5M more than expected. Early results for 2019 show a similar pattern. #VTBudget

We’ll be able to triple the number of barracks where we embed [social workers], which will reduce the volume of emergency calls, hospitalizations and court involvement for some of our most vulnerable Vermonters, all within existing resources. #VTBudget

I’d like to pilot a new mental health Mobile Response Unit. In other states, this model has reduced emergency room visits and hospital admissions, saved many hours of law enforcement time and helped foster kids find stability. #VTBudget

Tragically, suicide is a growing risk around the country, and we know all too well Vermont is not immune. Our approach must focus on early intervention for those at risk. That’s why my budget invests over $1 million more in suicide prevention & mental health services. #VTBudget

(3/3) Coupled with the universal afterschool network I proposed in the State of the State and expanding mental health services in schools, we can prevent serious problems before they develop and give every child the hope and opportunity they need and deserve. #VTBudget
(2/3) ...reduced costs of child protection, special education, substance abuse and criminal justice services down the road and put families on a path to economic self-sufficiency. #VTBudget

(1/3) By investing $1M more in our newborn home visiting program, we can cover roughly 1/4 of all the babies born each year, giving these parents the support they need to build a better foundation for their kids. This model has improved the health of babies and moms... #VTBudget

My budget prioritizes spending to prevent root causes rather than just treat consequences... to find efficiencies, make structural changes & create savings in order to reinvest in areas that prevent problems in the first place which will further reduce costs over time. #VTBudget

Our demographic crisis is without question the greatest challenge we face as a state... But here’s the thing: We can fix it, so long as we resist the temptation to ignore it, get distracted by politics or become deterred by hard work. #VTBudget
(2/2) And even with consistent revenue growth, each year we’ve had to make difficult decisions with reductions to agencies, departments, programs and services. #VTBudget

(1/2) The General Fund budget I’m presenting spends $1.7 billion, which is an increase of 2.8% or $46 million over the current year. Here’s the frustrating part: Even with organic revenue growth, we still started building our General Fund budget with a $70 million gap. #VTBudget

(2/2) ...student performance and the number of kids continue to decrease. Since Act 60 was passed, we’ve lost 26,000 students from our K-12 public schools while education spending has more than doubled. #VTBudget

(1/2) In the Education Fund... we project spending to total over $1.8 billion, an $87 million, 5% increase over the current year. Unfortunately, we’re seeing spending, property taxes, as well as inequity, continue to increase while educational opportunities... #VTBudget
We’re now in the second year of the $124 million capital bill. I’ll propose a few changes... but we remain on target in most areas. #VTBudget

(2/2) This includes $100M for roads and paving, major projects like the new draw bridge in Grand Isle & our rail project in Middlebury... It provides for 158 new park and ride spaces, investments in bike and ped projects and so much more. #VTBudget

(1/2) The transportation budget includes $276.7M in state funds... leveraging another $335.6M in federal funds. This amounts to a $25.5M increase... the largest transportation budget since the Irene recovery, without raising additional taxes or fees. #VTBudget

This is the approach we took, and in the upcoming fiscal year, across all funds, our budget totals $6.3 billion. With $4.2 billion of state revenue sources and $2.1 billion in federal dollars, this is an increase of about 2% over the current year. #VTBudget

With each budget proposal, I’ve focused on our fiscal fundamentals, to balance what we want with what we need and to set us on a path where our capacity to solve problems and help people grows while the burden on taxpayers shrinks. #VTBudget

It’s my belief the state budget should not grow any faster than people’s paychecks. Our goal should be to do our work in ways that help Vermonters keep more of what they earn, making it easier—not harder—for every family to live a secure and stable life. #VTBudget

If our sense of service and duty is strong; if our commitment to our neighbors is unwavering; and if we remember that we are all part of something bigger than ourselves, then the state of the state, our future and our people will be stronger than ever before. #VTSOTS

When [difficult] moments come, I think of the people who inspire me to be part of something bigger, of what they’ve endured with courage and resolve, and how they show that in the face of incredible adversity, we’re all capable of great things. #VTSOTS

Over the next few months, the way we go about our work will not only determine the results we’re able to deliver but also the strength of our institutions, the faith Vermonters have in us and the example we set for our kids. #VTSOTS

I’ll also propose a package of criminal justice reforms that we’ve shared with the comms. of jurisdiction… As we continue to create a more effective criminal justice system, we must remember that justice for victims & accountability for criminals must be top priorities. #VTSOTS

Many of you, alongside the Agency of Human Services, have worked diligently to improve our mental health system. This includes adding inpatient capacity, which is critical to getting people the care they need, when they need it. #VTSOTS

We took significant steps over the last year to protect kids: passing legislation to address the vaping epidemic and to ensure drinking water at every school and child care center will be tested for lead. And this work will continue. #VTSOTS

(3/3) ...as well as expanding our battery and renewable energy storage sectors and the jobs they can create. And I’ll propose giving small co-ops and municipal utilities more flexibility in order to innovate. #VTSOTS

(2/3) As we look even further ahead, I strongly believe it’s incentives, not penalties, which will help us transition more quickly... My budget will propose more incentives and a greater focus on affordable, clean energy... #VTSOTS

(1/3) We know about half of the emissions that contribute to climate change come from transportation. That’s why we’ve also worked together to make it more affordable to purchase electric vehicles. #VTSOTS

(2/2) And, when paired with my proposed investments in housing & economic development, will support more vibrant, walkable & livable downtowns & villages which, as the Speaker has said, supports economic growth & is a critical piece of our work to combat climate change. #VTSOTS

(1/2) I also appreciate the sense of urgency Speaker Johnson and others have placed on modernizing Act 250… The balanced approach we’re working on would enable concentrated development where people want to live & work. #VTSOTS

Because of the economic imbalance from region to region, I still hear about the difficulty of finding an affordable place to live. That’s why my budget will include a package to revitalize existing homes and build more of them, targeted to the places that need it most. #VTSOTS

I propose to you today that we begin creating a universal afterschool network that ensures every child has access to enrichment opportunities outside of current classroom time, and to align the students’ day with the length of the workday. #VTSOTS

(2/2) Because, ultimately, we need to help people in all parts of the state move up the economic ladder, and the best way to do this is to level the economic playing field and make Vermont more affordable for all families and every business. #VTSOTS
(1/2) Overall tax and fee burden is still growing far too fast, especially property taxes, and you can expect additional targeted tax relief in my budget. #VTSOTS

@VermontSOS (3/3) …my budget will include additional investments in training, with an emphasis on the trades and more incentives for young adults and working-age families to stay or move here. #VTSOTS

(2/3) And we're helping those in recovery or with other barriers to employment find and keep good jobs... In partnership with @VermontSOS let’s further reduce hurdles and costs for licensed professionals so we can bring more of them into the workforce. #VTSOTS

(1/3) We’re strengthening training, internship & apprenticeship programs for VTers. We established a first-in-the-nation approach to make it easy for veterans to transition to civilian careers. #VTSOTS

@VTEconDev (2/2) We know this isn’t the only answer, but this program is a small step towards growing our way out of the demographic crisis facing our state and the affordability crisis facing our families. #VTSOTS @VTEconDev

(1/2) Since [the launch of the remote worker incentive], we’ve received worldwide attention, more than $7 million in free advertising, thousands of inquiries and relocated 371 people to more than 68 communities across 13 counties. #VTSOTS @VTEconDev
(3/3) ...then our businesses and economy will grow, putting more kids in our schools and broadening our tax base, making our communities stronger and more resilient than ever before. #VTSOTS
(2/3) ...if we focus on the fundamentals: a better, more modern government, a stronger fiscal foundation and policy that’s truly equitable... #VTSOTS

(1/3) If we’re willing to focus on doing the work, on caring more about the details than we do the talking points; if we can build consensus and trust and avoid national political agendas deliberately designed to divide us... #VTSOTS

Sustainable, economic growth has become too hard & too rare in too many areas. It’s hurting people. It’s regressive. It’s creating regional inequity. And it’s by far the biggest & most immediate challenge to our state & the ability of government to help shape the future. #VTSOTS

This is what a demographic crisis looks like. In too many places, and in the lives of too many Vermonters, I see and feel the emotional and financial toll of policies built for a few areas in the state that can afford them when the rest of the state cannot. #VTSOTS

From county to county, there’s a huge gap between median home values, median household income, average wage & so much more... across the state, we’re feeling the negative impacts in everything from our homes, schools & colleges to our hospitals & nursing homes. #VTSOTS

Of the five towns that have seen the most growth in recent years, four of them are in Chittenden County. And in the past 12 years, only three counties have added workers. The other 11 have lost a total of about 18,000. #VTSOTS

Today in Vermont, there are about 55,000 fewer people under the age of 45 and 44,000 more over the age of 65 than there were in the year 2000. For years, we had more deaths than births, and have seen more people move out of Vermont than in. #VTSOTS
(2/2) So, even as we face major challenges, these Vermonters show that in the hands of our people, doing all they can every day, the state of the state is strong. #VTSOTS

(1/2) These people and thousands more—those we hear about and those we don’t—remind us that we are all part of something bigger, and that it’s in our pursuit of purpose and in service to others that we find the best of ourselves, our communities, our state and our nation. #VTSOTS

The state of the state, our values and identity are guided by—but have never been defined by—what happens in this building. It’s the people of Vermont, doing all they can to lift each other up, who will shape our future. They define who we are and all we can be. #VTSOTS

While good things are happening and progress is being made, too many of our counties, communities and families remain at a critical crossroad. The fact is, where we are as a state, and where we go from here, is in the hands of every Vermonter. #VTSOTS

This, my fellow Vermonters, is how we rise above partisanship, how we reject polarization, how we work toward something bigger than ourselves and how we—all of us in this room—can best lead our nation forward. #VTSOTS

In state houses and town halls across America, it’s up to us to show that people from different backgrounds, with different points of view, can unite around our core values and our common humanity. #VTSOTS

As elected officials, it’s our duty to distinguish what must be done from what we might like to do, and to work together, pulling in the same direction, to make a difference for those we serve. #VTSOTS
